learning_outcomes.description: Demonstrate knowledge of the central issues affecting contemporary understandings of Australia as a nation
Be able to compare, contrast, and analyse a range of different perspectives on current debates about Australian society and culture
Be able to make links between individual identities and national identities
Show reasonable knowledge of the historical context of current issues and recognise ways in which history is re-interpreted to meet contemporary needs
Demonstrate an understanding of concepts and methods important to the field of Australian Studies

assessments.task_description:
This assessment takes place over a total of 10 workshops starting in Week 2 (2/03/2026)

There will be 10 workshop assessment activities in total each worth 3%.

Each workshop will consist of a selection of activities designed to expand and assess your understanding of the weekly topics. Workshop activities will further provide you with the opportunity to develop your skills in critical thinking, language development, communication, written literacy, observation and interpretation of media texts, and visual literacy.

You must actively take part in all workshop activities to recieve a maximum mark of 3%.

Specific details of each workshop, the activities you will be completing, and how to prepare for the workshop will be provided in advance on Blackboard. You will be required to read the instructions carefully and prepare for workshops before attending.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be completed in person in workshops only.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment you will be required to choose an academic reading from the list provided on Blackboard. You will be required to respond to a set of questions about the reading designed to develop your ability to develop skills in critical thinking and the ability to question, analyse, interpret, evaluate, and synthesise information.

Further instructions, including specific questions, assessment guidelines, grading criteria, and sample assessment will be available on Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
For this assessment you will be required to choose an academic reading from the list provided on Blackboard. You will be required to respond to a set of questions about the reading designed to develop your ability to develop skills in critical thinking and the ability to question, analyse, interpret, evaluate, and synthesise information.

You must choose a different academic reading on a different topic to your Focused Analysis 1.

You must incorporate feedback you received from Focused Analysis 1.

assessments.task_description:
You have been asked to curate an exhibition that provides a multidimensional narrative about contemporary Australia. Your exhibition should not reproduce tired cliches and stereotypes about Australian identity, nor will your exhibition necessarily be a 'positive' or celebratory representation of the nation. Instead, it should seek to present Australia in new ways. The idea is to demonstrate what you have learned from the course by applying it creatively and meaningfully to media objects around us.

Your exhibition will consist of five items and must address five different topics from Weeks 3 –11 of the course.

Items must be originally sourced by you, NOT copied from the course material or workshops.

Items should encompass a range of different media. For example, original photographs (that you have taken) of street art, posters, graffiti, statues, event notices. Cartoons, gallery art, music videos, poetry, screen media, social media. Be creative! As long as you can make a credible case that the item provides a representation of contemporary Australia.

Each item will be accompanied by a 100-word (+/- 10%) explanation/caption that actively engages with a minimum of 1 academic, peer-reviewed resource from the course (i.e. a minimum of 1 academic source per explanation/caption).

In addition, you will include a 1500-word (+/- 10%) rationale that contextualises your choice of exhibition items and what understandings of nation/national identify are conveyed by your items. You must support all claims in your rationale with evidence and include a full reference list (not included in the word count).

Full guidelines, marking criteria, and examples will be provided on Blackboard.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 1: Introduction

This week we will go through important information related to the course including Blackboard, assessments, learning approaches and what to expect. We will also begin looking at key critical issues and debates that have shaped, and continue to influence Australia today.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 1: Introduction This week we will go through important information related to the course including Blackboard, assessments, learning approaches and what to expect. We will also begin looking at key critical issues and debates that have shaped, and continue to influence Australia today.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 2: Visual Thinking Strategies

This week we will begin with a Visual Thinking Strategy Session, presented by the UQ Art Museum. This session will be vital to the development of critical thinking skills needed for this course as well your learning journey more broadly. VTS teaches learners to carefully observe, evaluate, synthesise, justify and speculate – all essential aspects for critical thinking. It has been measured as an effective tool to build visual thinking skills, which directly benefits graduate performance, including exam results.


Learning outcomes: L05
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 2: Visual Thinking Strategies This week we will begin with a Visual Thinking Strategy Session, presented by the UQ Art Museum. This session will be vital to the development of critical thinking skills needed for this course as well your learning journey more broadly. VTS teaches learners to carefully observe, evaluate, synthesise, justify and speculate – all essential aspects for critical thinking. It has been measured as an effective tool to build visual thinking skills, which directly benefits graduate performance, including exam results.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 3: Australian National Identity: Mythology, Power, and Privilege

This week we will critically examine some prominent myths about Australian national identity such as the myth of Terra Nullius, the myth of Egalitarianism and ‘a fair go’, and the ANZAC myth. We will ask questions such as: Whose interests do these mythologies serve? Who is included and who is rendered invisible? What do these mythologies tell us about Australia politically, socially, and culturally?
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 3: Australian National Identity: Mythology, Power, and Privilege
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 3: Australian National Identity: Mythology, Power, and Privilege This week we will critically examine some prominent myths about Australian national identity such as the myth of Terra Nullius, the myth of Egalitarianism and ‘a fair go’, and the ANZAC myth. We will ask questions such as: Whose interests do these mythologies serve? Who is included and who is rendered invisible? What do these mythologies tell us about Australia politically, socially, and culturally?

learning_activities.topic:
Week 4: Indigenous Identities: Activism and Resistance

This week we will explore historical events that have shaped First Nations Peoples. We will look at government policies that have, and continue to, impacted First Nations peoples. We will also explore acts of resistance and activism by First Nation people from Australia’s first wars, the establishment of the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra, Nicky Winmar’s stand against racial discrimination, and more.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 4: Indigenous Identities: Activism and Resistance This week we will explore historical events that have shaped First Nations Peoples. We will look at government policies that have, and continue to, impacted First Nations peoples. We will also explore acts of resistance and activism by First Nation people from Australia’s first wars, the establishment of the Aboriginal Tent Embassy in Canberra, Nicky Winmar’s stand against racial discrimination, and more.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 5: Multicultural Identities in Australia

The first migrants to Colonial Australia were prisoners of the British Crown who were transported to the country as punishment. Since then, there have been different waves of immigration that have established Australia as a multicultural nation - an identity that has been subject to both celebration and controversy. This week we will track historical attitudes, policies, and practices that have informed cultural ideas about immigration and national identity.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 5: Multicultural Identities in Australia The first migrants to Colonial Australia were prisoners of the British Crown who were transported to the country as punishment. Since then, there have been different waves of immigration that have established Australia as a multicultural nation - an identity that has been subject to both celebration and controversy. This week we will track historical attitudes, policies, and practices that have informed cultural ideas about immigration and national identity.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 6: Gender and sexuality in Contemporary Australia

This week we will look at hegemony and how tropes and ideologies about gender operate to maintain hegemonic power structures. However, our main focus will be to explore diverse, historically overlooked gender identities in Australian society.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 6: Gender and sexuality in Contemporary Australia
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 6: Gender and sexuality in Contemporary Australia This week we will look at hegemony and how tropes and ideologies about gender operate to maintain hegemonic power structures. However, our main focus will be to explore diverse, historically overlooked gender identities in Australian society.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 7: Truth Telling & Treaty

With the first treaty between Indigenous people and the Australian government recently passed in Victoria law recently, this is an opportune time to discuss why treaty is significant, what truth telling is, and why it is essential to reconciliation.
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 7: Truth Telling & Treaty With the first treaty between Indigenous people and the Australian government recently passed in Victoria law recently, this is an opportune time to discuss why treaty is significant, what truth telling is, and why it is essential to reconciliation.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 8: Refugees and Asylum Seekers: Policies and Practice

As we saw in Week 5, Colonial Australia has history of discrimination when it comes to the country’s borders and who it will allow in, dating back to the implementation of the Immigration Restriction Act, in 1901. Since the mid-1980s Australian governments have increasingly implemented hard lined immigration policies that has led the UN to warn that Australia's mandatory detention regime for refugees and asylum seekers is violating international human rights. This week we will examine some of the issues facing refugees and asylum seekers.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 8: Refugees and Asylum Seekers: Policies and Practice
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 8: Refugees and Asylum Seekers: Policies and Practice As we saw in Week 5, Colonial Australia has history of discrimination when it comes to the country’s borders and who it will allow in, dating back to the implementation of the Immigration Restriction Act , in 1901. Since the mid-1980s Australian governments have increasingly implemented hard lined immigration policies that has led the UN to warn that Australia's mandatory detention regime for refugees and asylum seekers is violating international human rights. This week we will examine some of the issues facing refugees and asylum seekers.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 9: Autographic Practice: Agency, Advocacy, and Representation

This week we will look at the way asylum seekers, First Nations, and culturally/gender diverse people use autobiographical comics to voice issues of subjectivity, embodiment, and belonging. This week’s topic is designed to inspire you and get you thinking creatively about your digital exhibition concept and rationale.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 9: Autographic Practice: Agency, Advocacy, and Representation
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 9: Autographic Practice: Agency, Advocacy, and Representation This week we will look at the way asylum seekers, First Nations, and culturally/gender diverse people use autobiographical comics to voice issues of subjectivity, embodiment, and belonging. This week’s topic is designed to inspire you and get you thinking creatively about your digital exhibition concept and rationale.

learning_activities.topic: PUBLIC HOLIDAY: NO SEMINARS THIS WEEK
learning_activities.topic_description: PUBLIC HOLIDAY: NO SEMINARS THIS WEEK

learning_activities.topic:
Week 11: Contemporary Australia and Counternarratives on Social Media

This week we will continue our exploration of alternative modes of contemporary storytelling by looking at the way Australian film makers and artists are using Social Media platforms to share alternative, culturally diverse narratives.
learning_activities.topic_title: Week 11: Contemporary Australia and Counternarratives on Social Media
learning_activities.topic_description: Week 11: Contemporary Australia and Counternarratives on Social Media This week we will continue our exploration of alternative modes of contemporary storytelling by looking at the way Australian film makers and artists are using Social Media platforms to share alternative, culturally diverse narratives.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 12: Contemporary Australia in Focus

This week we will re-cap salient points from the course topics with a focus on the Digital Exhibition Concept and Rationale. We will allow space to examine any significant social, cultural, or political events that have arisen during the semester. We will also undertake activities designed to help you put your digital exhibition collection together.  

Learning outcomes: L05

We will allow space to examine any significant social, cultural, or political events that have arisen during the semester. We will also undertake activities designed to help you put your digital exhibition collection together.

learning_activities.topic:
Week 13: Independent Study Week

There will be no seminars this week. Instead it will be a time for you to finalise your Digital Exhibition Concept and Rationale.
